title: How to understand 'Much' in the sentence 'Much to the timid writer's chagrin, the audience chanted his name until he came back on the stage.' - Quora

response.answer_text: The job of the ‘much’ in this sentence is to emphasize that the writer was not pleased, that he felt discomfort in this situation. Rather than saying: ‘The writer was a timid man, and so he felt pretty uncomfortable when the audience began chanting his name to bring him back on stage’ - this writer has chosen to stress the ‘chagrin’ the subject of the sentence feels in a more concise, powerful way. This type of writing is an example of the flexibility of the English language, and how you can choose to depict situations in different ways. With this sentence there is no mistaking that the writer is someone who normally avoids the spotlight. Much, here is working as an alternative way of composing the sentence, there are many examples of this use of ‘much’: ‘Much to my surprise, the birthday cake exploded and a naked woman emerged’ ‘Much to the mayor’s displeasure, his opponent was making a very clear argument to the contrary’. And so on.
Much in that usage is an adverb of degree. Parallel adverbs expressing other degrees of chagrin would be “Somewhat to the timid writer's chagrin…”; “Greatly to…”; “A little to...”--you get the idea.
